Introduction

Personality disorders cause rigidity in thinking (eg, perception of self, others, and situations), feeling (eg, emotional range and reactivity), and behaving (eg, ability to establish/maintain relationships, impulse control).  Characteristics of personality disorders are present by early adulthood and are generally stable across time and situations (eg, social, occupational, personal), causing significant functional impairment and/or distress.

Epidemiology



The estimated prevalence of personality disorders in the general population is 10%.  Clinical and incarcerated populations have higher prevalence rates.

Types of personality disorders



There are 10 personality disorders grouped into 3 clusters based on shared features:  cluster A (odd, eccentric), cluster B (dramatic, emotional, erratic), and cluster C (anxious, fearful).

Cluster A (odd, eccentric)

Paranoid personality disorder



  • Characteristics:  distrust and suspiciousness of being exploited or deceived by others; unforgiving of slights/insults; preoccupation with doubting the loyalty of others, including spousal/partner fidelity.
  • Treatment:  cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) to identify paranoid thoughts and their effects on emotions/behaviors as well as quality of life; improve interpersonal skills.
  • Prognosis:  largely dependent on ability to engage/progress in treatment and build trust with providers; left untreated, paranoid personality disorder can cause significant social and occupational impairment.

Schizoid personality disorder



  • Characteristics:  does not enjoy or desire social relationships; limited emotional expression; preference for solitary activities.
  • Treatment:  cognitive-behavioral approaches focusing on developing social skills and increasing emotional awareness may be beneficial.
  • Prognosis:  improved for those in lifestyles and occupations that do not heavily rely on interpersonal functioning.

Schizotypal personality disorder



  • Characteristics:  discomfort and decreased capacity for close relationships; excessive social anxiety due to paranoid fears of others' motives; odd beliefs and magical thinking (eg, belief in telepathy); unusual perceptual experiences (eg, sensing another's aura).
  • Treatment:  primarily supportive and/or exploratory psychotherapy (eg, psychodynamic psychotherapy) to improve self-awareness of maladaptive thoughts and behaviors; adjunct treatment with low-dose second generation antipsychotics may be of benefit for severe paranoia and perceptual distortions.
  • Prognosis:  chronic condition for most, though improved for those consistently engaged in treatment.

Cluster B (dramatic, emotional, erratic)

Antisocial personality disorder (ASPD)



  • Characteristics:  unlawful behaviors (eg, harassment, sexual assault); deceitfulness (eg, fraudulent activities); impulsivity and recklessness (eg, driving while intoxicated); physical aggression; lack of remorse.
  • Treatment:  psychotherapy has not been shown to be effective; treatment focuses on improvement of comorbid conditions (substance use disorders, mood disorders).
  • Prognosis:  chronic course, although some behaviors may decrease in middle adulthood (eg, age 40-50).

Borderline personality disorder (BPD)



  • Characteristics:  unstable self-image and relationships; impulsivity (eg, substance use, binge eating); affective instability; recurrent suicidality or self-injurious behaviors.
  • Treatment:  primarily psychotherapy; multiple effective options, including dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) and transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP); focus on emotional regulation, distress tolerance, and development of coping skills; pharmacotherapy used as an adjunct in severe cases of mood instability (mood stabilizer) or transient paranoia (second-generation antipsychotic).
  • Prognosis:  elevated suicidality risk (10% of patients die by suicide); majority of patients experience sustained remission with treatment.

Histrionic personality disorder



  • Characteristics:  rapidly shifting and exaggerated emotions; attention seeking; sexually seductive/provocative behaviors and appearance.
  • Treatment:  psychotherapy has limited effectiveness; treatment primarily focuses on management of comorbid conditions (somatic symptom disorder, conversion disorder, depression).
  • Prognosis:  chronic course, though may improve with engagement in therapy and treatment of comorbid conditions.

Narcissistic personality disorder



  • Characteristics:  grandiose sense of self-importance; preoccupied with fantasies of success and power; need for excessive admiration; interpersonally exploitative; lacking in empathy.
  • Treatment:  primarily psychotherapy to identify distorted thoughts and maladaptive behaviors as well as improve interpersonal functioning; options include psychodynamic psychotherapy, TFP, and DBT.
  • Prognosis:  variable and dependent on level of functioning, engagement in treatment, and presence of comorbid conditions; aggression is a poor prognostic indicator.

Cluster C (anxious, fearful)

Avoidant personality disorder



  • Characteristics:  socially inhibited, sense of inadequacy, hypersensitivity to criticism resulting in avoidance of interpersonal situations.
  • Treatment:  CBT may help identify and reframe negative cognitions about self-worth and lessen social anxiety.


  • Prognosis:  dependent on engagement in treatment; comorbid conditions (depression, social anxiety disorder) are common and typically associated with a poorer prognosis; symptoms may remit with age.

Dependent personality disorder



  • Characteristics:  requires excessive reassurance for everyday decisions; fear of separation resulting in submissive behaviors; fear of being alone and unable to care for self.


  • Treatment:  CBT or psychodynamic psychotherapy to identify maladaptive patterns of behavior and increase self-awareness and self-efficacy.


  • Prognosis:  chronic course, though may improve with treatment; comorbid conditions (depression, anxiety disorders) are common.

Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD)



  • Characteristics:  excessive preoccupation with order and details; perfectionism that impedes task completion; devotion to work/productivity; inflexible morals, ethics, and values; minimal spending of money to save for future catastrophes.
  • Treatment:  CBT or psychodynamic psychotherapy to explore insecurities and negative cognitions about self that result in rigidity and need for control.
  • Prognosis:  chronic course, though positive prognostic indicators include insight into symptoms and engagement with therapy.

Summary



Personality disorders (
